user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of call_connection_handler:
```c
static void
call_connection_handler (struct MHD_Connection *connection)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = connection->daemon;
  size_t processed;

  if (NULL != connection->rp.response)
    return;                     /* already queued a response */
  processed = 0;
  connection->rq.client_aware = true;
  connection->in_access_handler = true;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context))
  {
    connection->in_access_handler = false;
    /* serious internal error, close connection */
    CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR (connection,
                            _ ("Application reported internal error, " \
                               "closing connection."));
    return;
  }
  connection->in_access_handler = false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
if (MHD_NO ==
      daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context))

daemon->default_handler (daemon->default_handler_cls,
                               connection,
                               connection->rq.url,
                               connection->rq.method,
                               connection->rq.version,
                               NULL,
                               &processed,
                               &connection->rq.client_context)
explanation: This function snippet contains no direct calls to any <string.h> routines (memcpy, strcpy, strcat, strlen, etc.). The only places that could lead to out-of-bounds accesses via string.h calls are the string pointers passed into the external callback default_handler. Therefore the invocation of daemon->default_handler and the string arguments (connection->rq.url, connection->rq.method, connection->rq.version) must be inspected in the context of that handler to ensure it does not call string.h functions in a way that accesses beyond the bounds of the referenced objects. Other statements in this function (checks on connection->rp.response, setting flags, processed variable, CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR, returns) do not themselves call or pass buffers to string.h functions and so do not need investigation for Rule 21.17 in this snippet.
